utterances: Hi.
How are you?
Good.
Okay.
I just wanted to make a comment.
I'm a young visual journalist.
I just got out of school about a year and a half ago.

And one of the things that I found really fascinating about the newspaper industry now is that the younger generation is coming into the workplace with a lot of the new skills, new technology and have kind of a better understanding of the way that the Web is working and where it used to be, at least, I feel like in the newspaper industry, that experience is really what kind of pushed the newspaper industry forward.

A lot of the younger generation are bringing new skills that are kind of hoping change the industry, and it's just an interesting paradigm that you have people with less experience but with more - a better understanding of the skills than what's needed to push the industry whereas the older generation is (unintelligible) kind of consult us on how the industry needs to go.
So you feel that some of the older generation of journalist you're working with are beginning to feel that they've got to learn this.
Is that kind of what's happening?
A number of Tea Party leaders say they don't tolerate racist displays.
And Williams contends that it's actually the NAACP that's bigoted.
One Czech activist says he'd quit fighting the instillation if it were a full-fledged NATO project instead.
Yeah.

I mean, I don't want to sound, you know, like we're taking over the industry but I think it's interesting with this new technology particularly video and all the online efforts that are being done in the news industry, it's an incredible time for the younger generation to step in and help expand the platform and help push media in a new direction.
All right.
Good point.
I had to say, as a member of the news media, I think you might be right.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Well, it's great talking to you.
It's my first time calling a radio station so I was a little nervous but thanks for having me.
You did very well.
Thank you so much.
Take care.
We hear the same thing from editors and by the way, they say, Manuel, it's also cost less to hire than the old guy or who doesn't have those skills.
And the other thing, what's really happening, you know, in real terms, is what he's pointing up is that everybody has to do more.
Yeah.
And if you cannot adapt then you're an impediment to the newsroom which is trying desperately to figure out what's the potential of the new technology.
Yeah.

Let me just ask one other question about the blogs you were saying, it's, you know, you were saying - I think your report is saying it's not playing a central role as you expected but it's still, people love to go to blogs and read blogs and, you know, if you're, for instance, I cover books, you know, I read the newspapers but I go to the - there's a whole - there's the literary blogs and then there's the economic blogs and people know where they want to go for their own blogs.
Yes, and people are using blogs but that not as a substitute to traditional media but as a complement.
So that we're sort of that we're making room on the shelf for that.
All right.
Tom, good talking to you about this again.
Thanks, Lynn.
We'll probably talk same time next year.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Tom Rosenstiel is the director of the Project for Excellence in Journalism.
Their new report on the state of the news media is just out.
This is TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
I'm Lynn Neary.
This is WEEKEND EDITION from NPR News.
I'm Audie Cornish.
The National Tea Party Convention wraps up today in Nashville with a keynote speech tonight by a hero of the movement, former Alaska Governor Sarah Palin.
Yesterday, the event's organizers said they're starting a political action committee and a separate non-profit corporation to solicit donations to fund conservative candidates and causes.
NPR's Don Gonyea reports.
There are 600 activists who paid the $549 registration fee to attend this first-ever national convention for a movement that sprung up almost exactly a year ago.
For many, like William Temple, a retired government worker who came dressed in revolutionary costume, a chance to see former Alaska Governor Palin was a big draw.
Oh, I love the lady who kills moose.
She's the strongest mind in the Republican - Sarah Palin.
If I can get close enough, I'll give her a kiss.
I pledge allegiance to the flag of the United States of America.
Leading was the pledge was the conventions organizer, Judson Phillips, a Nashville lawyer who's been criticized by other Tea Party groups because this is a for-profit convention.

That controversy died down, but at a news conference he was asked if he supports remarks in a convention speech by former Republican Congressman Tom Tancredo, who called President Obama a committed socialist ideologue.
Phillips, who is new to this kind of attention, said Tancredo's speech was great but he spoke carefully, embracing the substance if not the red-hot tone.
The word socialist is a word that you don't want to be labeled with in the American political system.
And it's got a lot of negative connotations, but it also has a very specific political meaning.
It refers to a specific political ideology.
And I think it's very clear that that is the political ideology of Barack Obama.
Also helping to organize this week's event is Memphis-based Tea Party activist Mark Skoda.
He told reporters the movement has to find new ways to expand its reach.
Let us not be naï¿½ve here.
The notion of holding up signs and simply responding with emotions does not get people elected.
Skoda announced the creation of two entities - one: a nonprofit called the Insuring Liberty Corporation, a 501(c)(4), which can take corporate donations but is not required to disclose them.
And, he said, there'll be a separate political action committee.
He offered few details but implied that it's a way to create something that can help the movement without getting caught up in differences of opinion between various Tea Party groups.

While this is not the only way that the Tea Party movement can progress and mature, this is one way that we believe we can seek together the approach to counter, if you will, the fragmentation that exists today.
Though how setting up new outside organizations for fundraising accomplishes that is not entirely clear.
Also uncertain is the future of the movement itself.
It's growing in size and influence but whether it can hold together to have a lasting impact on the political landscape remains to be seen.
Don Gonyea, NPR News, Nashville.
This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
At the beginning of this school year, New York City began an anti-poverty program that pays low-income families for doing the right thing.
Parents, for example, can get $25 for attending a parent-teacher conference or 200 to take their kid to an annual check-up.
Students can get $25 a month for good attendance and $50 for getting a library card.
Emily Harris, NPR News, Prague.
At the other end of the graveyard, a traditional Moravian quartet is playing to entertain people as they work.
This tune is from 18th- century Germany.
It has been performed by generations.
Nola Reed Knouse heads the Moravian Music Foundation, an organization that works to preserve the group's vocal and instrumental traditions.
We as Moravians sing what we believe, and we sometimes say if we don't sing it, we don't believe it.
So that as we are hearing one of our particular tunes, most of us are singing those words in our heads, in our memories.
So it's a way of worship for us.
Unidentified Man #1: We're probably going to have close to 350, 400 players right here in the graveyard and maybe 5,000, 6,000 attendees.
So this is a big service.
A lot of us started playing in grade school, and we'll play until our last day, probably.
As they perform on Easter Sunday, Brown and Horner say it's an emotional experience to be surrounded by the graves of their ancestors.
Brown says he likes to think his grandparents and their grandparents before them are listening.
So he does his best to get the music right.
For NPR News, I'm Jessica Jones in Greensboro, North Carolina.
Time now for your letters.
(Soundbite of typing and music)
Several listeners pointed to parallels between two stories on last week's show.
The first featured Emma Thompson talking about an art installation that tells the story of 18-year-old Elena from Moldova who was trafficked into the sex industry.
The second was Italian mezzo-soprano Cecelia Bartoli performing arias made famous by castrati - boys who were castrated so their voices wouldn't change at puberty.
I was struck by the link between poverty, childhood survival, sexuality and exploitation.
Eighteen-year-old Moldavian Elena is a current example of the sacrifice of prepubescent boys in 18th century Europe.
Both involved powerful adults willing to exploit the lives of the poor to provide pleasure.
Both involved the destruction of life barely begun, to indulge the fantasies and restricted laws of nature or society.
Both exploit the mind of a child for momentary dream of a better life out of poverty.
